title: Ticket #469: condor_submits fails intermittently
description:
Says Fermi in the linked Rust ticket (which also contains logs and other history):

"Since the upgrade to condor 7.2.0 both on our submit client and on our general purpose grid cluster, we have started to see condor_submits fail intermittently for a number of different users. Retries of these condor_submits generally succeed. But the failures are very concerning and shouldn't be happening and never did happen before the upgrade. this is x86_64 condor 7.2.0 running on Sci. Linux 5."

We need to investigate this and/or provide a mechanism for condor_submit to have an intelligent retry policy --- by intelligent, I mean one that isn't going to make the load on an overloaded schedd worse.

GregT mentions another user which has relatively light schedd load, and yet reports that about 1 in 3000 submits fail -- so there may be something more insidious than just schedd load. Perhaps a correlation w/ start of negotiation cycle or ?
remarks:
2009-Nov-17 10:52:48 by zmiller:
since this isn't the kind of thing that is easily reproducible, we should at least run some of our own tests, submitting in a tight loop against schedds of varying business. perhaps this will yield some failures which can be analyzed.

2009-Nov-17 11:00:45 by matt:
I've had reports, and occasionally seen myself, condor_q get delayed or timeout occasionally.

To make any progress on this we'd need a better understanding of what "fail" means - is it just a delay, is it a timeout error, is it a failure during submission, and then some information about what the schedd is doing at the time of the failure.

2009-Dec-16 08:30:18 by matt:
Suggested workaround is to increase condor_submit's timeout with TIMEOUT_MULTIPLIER, e.g. SUBMIT_TIMEOUT_MULTIPLIER = 3. The default timeout is 20 second, with a multiplier of 3 it will be 60 seconds. Presumably that will be enough to significantly decrease the likelihood of a timeout "failure".
